case_vignette: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother because of persistent crying and refusal to move his right arm. The episode began 30 minutes ago after the mother lifted him up by the arms. He appears distressed and is inconsolable. On examination, his right arm is held close to his body in a flexed and pronated position.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been crying a lot and not wanting to move my right arm.
How old are you?
I'm 2 years old.
Have you had any recent falls or injuries?
No, nothing like that.
Is there a family history of joint problems or arthritis?
I don't know about that.
Does your child have a fever?
No, there's no fever.
Has your child had any recent illnesses or infections?
No recent illnesses or infections.
**Final Diagnosis:** Nursemaid's Elbow (Radial Head Subluxation)

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been crying a lot and I don't want to move my right arm at all.
How old are you?
I'm 2 years old.
Has there been any recent injury or trauma to your right arm?
Yes, my mom lifted me up by the arms and then this started.
Does your right arm appear swollen or bruised?
No, it doesn't look swollen or bruised.
Do you have any trouble moving your fingers on your right hand?
You didn't ask me about that before, so I don't know.
I apologize for not asking earlier. Can you try to move your fingers on your right hand?
Yes, but I want to keep my arm close to my body and it's bent.
Is there a family history of bone or joint problems?
You didn't ask me about family history before, so I don't know.
I understand, I should have asked before. Thank you for your patience. Have you had any similar symptoms in the past?
I was previously healthy and haven't had this happen before.

Thank you for your responses. Based on your symptoms and history, it is likely that you have a "Nursemaid's Elbow," also known as a pulled elbow or a radial head subluxation. This is a common injury in young children and is typically caused by a sudden pulling or lifting of the arm. I recommend you see a doctor for further evaluation and treatment.

**Final Diagnosis:** Nursemaid's Elbow

trial_2.summarized_conversation: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a complaint of not being able to move their right arm after being lifted up by their mother. The child is unable to fully extend their arm and prefers to keep it close to their body. There is no visible swelling or bruising. The child has no previous history of this issue and was previously healthy. There is no mention of any family history related to this complaint.
trial_2.singleturn_mcq: **Final Diagnosis:** Supracondylar fracture of the humerus
